Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 06:16PM Charley wrote: I did 6 xTC DD and finished May, 2010.  I did not had have any hair (scalp) regrowth for 10 weeks PFC.  My hair is now approximately 1 1/2 inches long but I have a huge bald spot on the top of my head where hair is very thin. I am just hoping I can someday go without my wig and I am not one of the 3-6% that suffers with permanent loss. Also eyelashes are short and thin despite using latisse.  Eyebrows are also thin as is hair everywhere else.  <sigh> Charley
Posts.Title: Did anyone had her hair back after taxotere??? melania janet11

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 02:41PM Charley wrote: Thanks Bubba ... you are right. The nioxin is a shampoo/conditioner not an oral medication. I don't  know if it is worth it or not but since I have so little hair, one bottle lasts a long time. ;-) Oh and I am putting minoxidil on my head too! I started that a few months ago.  Yes, I did TCx6 DD and finished in May.  It was a full 8-10 weeks before I got even the 5 o'clock shadow. I am doing everything faithfully but who knows if it is really working or not. It sure is taking a long time.
Posts.Title: Did anyone had her hair back after taxotere??? melania janet11

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 05:46PM Charley wrote: Tracie - I have the smashbox eyebrow powder.  I got a good brush and when I had no eyebrows I used the wax to help keep the powder in place.  Even now that the eyebrows are back (well sort of) I continue to use it. It is great stuff!  bdavis, my hair didn't fall out until day 16 or 17. I did 6xTC DD ~ so every 2 weeks.  I had tons of hair too ... Losing it is the worst. I hope you aren't having too much trouble with SEs. Hang in there!  1 down ,,, 5 to go! Poodle - I don't know that you didn't do the right thing by just shaving itl off.  I just didn't have the guts to do it. I think I probably should shape up the uneven mop I have now but I can't bear to cut it!! (((Hugs))) Charley

Hoping to ditch the wig someday ...

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2010 05:31PM Charley wrote: And being one of those that lost her mother to breast cancer at age 10, I am reminded daily of how really terrible it is!  And now I have been diagnosed with breast cancer, I just pray that I have another 5 years to get my youngest through high school so hopefully he won't feel the hole in his life like I did. Unfortunately praying didn't seem to help my mother ... and we did alot of it. Sorry for your loss Jennifer.  Hugs, Charley
Posts.Title: Sad and just ****ing Angry!! JeninMichigan heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 09:41AM Charley wrote: I was told dose dense was better than traditional based on current studies but neulasta is necessary to do it. Your body is just unable to bring up the blood counts in a 2 week regime without it.  And yes!  Neulasta has its own side effects, of which, I had not fully been able to appreciate until my very last chemo session.  I did not have to take the neulasta shot this last time and the side effects I had experienced from neulasta - fever and bones aches for about 3 days - are nasty! Not that the side effects from TC are a walk in the park. If you can do the DD, I would recommend it.  My onc indicated if I wanted to go to a 3 week regime anytime during the process, I could.  Mentally I think that helped me but I wanted to do the best I could for myself and get it overwith so I stuck with it.
Posts.Title: Question about "Dose Dense" in_cognito my2boys

Posts.Content: Charley wrote: I just finished chemo on 5/19 and am anxious to get my port removed.  I will be doing exchange surgery in about 6 -8 weeks and thought that would be a good time to remove it.  The chemo nurses advised that they usually tell patients to leave the port in for at least a year due to frequent visits (every 3 mos) and related bloodwork.  Of course if I leave the port in I will have to get it flushed every 6 weeks so I will be seeing them much more often. At this point I am not anticipating anymore chemo.   Just wondering what others have experienced.  I don't want to go under anesthesia any more than necessary. Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2010 08:16PM Charley wrote: I now have fuzz on my head!  Almost 10 weeks PFC! And I actually had to pluck my brows (since they are growing in only the wrong places)  Eyelashes are falling out STILL. Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 01:16PM Charley wrote: KGB - So glad you are having an easy time of it!  I totally think that for some people SEs are not as bad.  I did 6 rounds of TC DD.  I took the neulasta shot with each one and wondered how much that could have contributed to my nasty side effects.  On the last treatment I did not take the shot and although fatigue was not easy, it was definitely not as severe. Hope things continue to go well for you!  You should keep posting about your positive experiences (hope they continue to be) as they give motivation to those who have yet to go through it and hope to those who are going through it!
Posts.Title: TC Chemo really not bad so far KGBinDC KGBinDC

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 09:50PM Charley wrote: Hi Ladies!  I was doing a search on neuropathy and taxotere so I'm bumping up this thread. I've had 3 TC treatments so far. My neuropathic symptoms have been subtle but worsening. I also noticed the cold feet all the time. They have felt kind of numb on the bottom, worse with walking, etc. and last night had a hard time falling asleep because of the strange feeling. Everything bothered my feet and they constantly felt like they were going to sleep. Palms feel strange too but not as bad. I hope it improves after chemo but sounds like some of you are still suffering with it!

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 11:44AM Charley wrote: Thank Fearless for bumping .. Great article!  That information was pretty much what my oncologist told me although since I do have lymph node involvement I think I may always have a nagging fear of reoccurrence.  Hopefully the TCx6 that I had last year totally obliterated any of the cancer cells that may have remained after BMX.  My aunt who turned 81 this year was diagnosed back in the early 70s.  No chemo then, but she did have MX + rads and had no problems since.  It will be interesting to see what the next few years will bring in regards to research and treatment.  Charley

Posts.Title: Why we can trust Dr. Tuohy's new cancer vaccine Terry3N BaseballFan

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 09:08PM Charley wrote: If you are having a needle biopsy (where they take out a bit of tissue from different areas from the lump as opposed to fine needle aspiration where they just draw out fluid), I have had that.  It was done at the breast center that also did the ultrasound.  They numb you up pretty good and basically stick a long needle into your breast that has the ability to "get" tiny portions of the lump.  It was not painful, although somewhat uncomfortable, and a little unnerving if you are watching the entire thing on the ultrasound!  I know it's easy to worry but you won't know exactly what you are dealing with until you get the path back.  In my case, the radiologist was able to confirm to me, that most likely, based on the presentation I had, it was cancer.  Take a deep breath.  It could be something else.  Even if its not, there are lots of excellent treatments out there.  You are doing what you can at this point.  Hang in there! Hugs, Charley
